comments.text:
I told you I don't need your approval, if you're genuine I'm doing this for 
your sake. You don't have to believe me, and it's not right that you act 
like you know me. My mom's not the smartest sometimes, but she's also a 
nurse and kept checking up on me. She also lost my little sister at a young 
age to a bunch of medical problems. So she was probably hanging onto the 
hope that I would just wake up and not turn out like my sister. If she saw 
a change in my condition she'd bring me in. After all, her job is being a 
nurse and she did already take care of my quadriplegic sister. I'm sorry I 
can't fit into a neat little box that you can consider truth. I feel sorry 
for you, I really do.

every studio class gave assignments that took up way too much time.. night 
paintings... day paintings... portraits. .. photo developing. . And 
sculptures Smh) my parents came to school to pick me up. . Noticed 
something was wrong. .I started throwing up. ...annnd turns out my kidneys 
and liver DID NOT like this abuse I did to my body. 

Moral of the story. .. Please go to sleep. ..I will never do that again. 
..I call it on 48 hours now. ..﻿

top_comment.author: 23CreepyPsycho23

comments.text:
23CreepyPsycho23 had a short and good question:



    "why does energy come in waves when you're sleep deprived ?"

The first response, by sunmarsh, was short and very good:
    "See circadian rhythm."

End of story.
comments.author: N. B. Macdonald

comments.text:
I think it comes and goes in waves because of how familiar our brains are 
to getting energy after sleep. When its late in the 24-hour period that you 
started to not sleep, you get to feel very tired. However, around the 
36-hour mark, when you would usually be waking up or already awake, our 
brains send out the same 'refreshed, energized' feelings you would feel 
when having gone through sleep.

In a shorter, less jarbled way of saying it, our brains have naturally done 
to themselves what Pavlov did to his dogs.

http://psychology.about.com/od/classicalconditioning/a/pavlovs-dogs.htm

Went for 3 full days, 72 hours without sleep when I was 20.  Me and a few 
friends did it to raise money for Band aid back in 84.  By the end of it 
only me and one of my friends were still awake and we were very irritable, 
jumpy and I remember my friend had hallucinations about spiders hiding just 
on the edge of his sight.  I kept thinking I could hear people whispering 
and kept catching glimpses of indistinct figures in the hallway of the flat 
we used.  It was the flat that one of us lived in, not mine.  Not something 
I would like to go through again.

top_comment.text:
I recently went through a major depressive episode, and I get insomnia when 
I'm depressed. At the same time, I was sleeping in a place that was bad for 
my allergies. Also, I was starting a new job, so had to get up on time 
every morning... it was awful. I was getting four to five hours of terrible 
sleep a night for several weeks on end. I'm not sure what was worse - the 
sleep deprecation or the depression... neither helped the other. I was 
falling asleep at work, spacing out while driving, having irrational 
thought patterns... it was awful. 

(Thankfully, I got a great therapist, a good doctor, and a high-quality 
allergy cover. I'm not 100%, but my feet are back under me!) ﻿

Welp, Ive pulled off consistent all-nighters for 2 weeks (i did begin to 
sleep on a regular bases after the two weeks) approximately 4 months ago. 
However, i did regard the condition as being normal because i did change my 
sleep schedule. That is to say that i went to sleep at 5 am to about 2 pm, 
consistently (basically being a nocturnal organism). May we say that this 
has no particular effect, or? Anyone with knowledge as to any specifics 
please reply.﻿
top_comment.author: Jon Alesbury

comments.text:
What I've experienced with this is that it don't have much effect if you're 
not doing anything requiring too much work (both physical and mental)... 
But if you start working on a paper, or go to work requiring you too do 
some physical work you'll start feeling tired pretty damn quickly compared 
too if you had a normal sleeping schedule.

My guess is that it's because of the body trying to tell you that you need 
to sleep because it's dark outside. Also I do believe that if you continue 
doing that for a long time (probably around 6+ months) your body will start 
adapting in the way of it starting to do the complete opposite (Telling you 
it's time to sleep when it's light outside).

Also there could be cases of people being places that's always light or 
dark. If the body had to adapt to that I would guess it would take even 
longer since the body would have to (to some extent) turn off this system 
and find another way to tell you that you need to sleep.
comments.author: Luckyshot

comments.text:
Your body uses light levels to clue it in on when it should sleep and when 
it should wake. There will be some effects, but so long as you still get 
enough restful sleep you shouldn't experience anything severe. If you're 
interested, look into studies of people who work graveyard shifts/night 
shifts.
comments.author: sunmarsh

comments.text:
it doesn't matter when you get sleep, as long as you get the sleep.  There 
are many people who work during the night and sleep during the daytime.  
There are also people who have irregular sleep patterns, like they sleep 5 
times a day for short periods of time and because they do it regularly on a 
schedule, the go right into REM sleep and actually become rested instead of 
it taking a long time to kick into REM sleep and feeling worse than they 
did before they tried to sleep.
comments.author: darkquail2003

comments.text:
Don't think that is really any cause for concern. Your still getting 
sufficient sleep even if its not at night time. I have been doing the same 
thing for over a month now, and have several times before and it never 
bothers me. Plenty of people who work graveyard shifts adapt that kind of 
sleep schedule all the time.

captions.text:
This episode of DNews was proudly made possible
by the all-new 2015 Subaru Legacy. It's not
just a sedan, it's a Subaru.

Howdy snooze buttons, Trace here snoring away
for DNews! We've talked a lot about sleep,

but while scientists have slowly been decoding
the secrets of animal naptime, we still don't

know exactly WHY we sleep. We DO know though,
that if we neglect it, we're screwed.

The world record for sleep deprivation is
264 hours of wakefulness, or about 11 days.

It was set by a high schooler in the mid-1960s.
Researchers routinely keep people awake for

a eight to ten days with no ill effects. But
that's not the same. By the way, this is sleep

deprivation. Sleep deprivation is different
from insomnia. According to the International

Classification of Sleep Disorders, Insomnia
is a nightly complaint of an insufficient

amount of sleep or not feeling rested after
the habitual sleep episode, while sleep deprivation

is when a person persistently fails to obtain
sufficient nocturnal sleep required to support

normally alert wakefulness. One happens TO
you, the other you're doing.

Both have the same result, though. Not sleeping.
When this happens, the human body responds,

poorly. To say the least. Physically, the
brain sends out hormones like cortisol -- the

stress hormone and TSH -- or thyroid stimulating
hormone, which regulates metabolism. Blood

pressure goes up, and your metabolism stops
processing glucose correctly creating food

cravings for carbs. The overall temperature
of the body will drop, and the immune system

slows down. Mentally, this causes problems
with attention and concentration, irritability,

depression, fatigue, decreased motivation
and if it goes on long enough, can seriously
mess up cognitive function altogether.

So again, it seems that sleep isn't just a
lovely retreat from the busy world, but also

necessary for life! Without it we can barely
survive! After a few days of sleep deprivation,

people begin to experience forced brain shutdowns
called microsleeps -- where the human brain

shuts down for just a second and goes into
sleep mode. During that time, the brain is

asleep, and the person loses motor function;
but not for long enough to feel rested. This

was happening to the high schooler who set
the 11-day world record.

In experiments at the University of Chicago,
lab technicians kept mice awake for about

two weeks before they died of whole body hypermetabolism.
In humans, Fatal Familial Insomnia strikes

in middle age, and as the name suggests it's
inherited and deadly. When someone in one

of the maybe 200 families in the world who
have FFI reaches middle age, they'll be unable

to sleep their autosomal systems break down
and they eventually die or total organ failure

after six to thirty, sleepless, months. Scientists
are reluctant to say that the lack of sleep

is what kills them, as the disease is actually
related to Mad Cow, more than anything else.

We probably CAN'T die from a lack of sleep
itself, but most scientific studies have found

psychological effects like paranoia and hallucination
take hold and prevent us from learning more

about the physical effects. Though sleep studies
HAVE shown purposefully depriving yourself

of sleep can increase risks for diabetes,
obesity, heart problems, depression, and of

course large equipment accidents thanks to
microsleeps.

If you need to recover from a lack of sleep,
just sleep! The guy who was awake for 11 days

slept for 14 hours and was pronounced completely
normal. There's no such thing as catching

up on sleep, but a true full night of sleep
will do you good, regardless.

What's the longest you've ever gone without
sleep? I went 40 hours on a road trip to watch

the last Space Shuttle launch. I was kept
awake by Dr. Pepper, candy, and extreme geek-itude.

Did you beat my record?
Share your sleepless nights in the comments

and be sure you subscribe for more DNews.
And say hello on Twitter too! I'm at-TraceDominguez!
Thanks for watching.

title: Can You Die From A Lack Of Sleep?
